title: Why did Napoleon dislike the British? - Quora

response.answer_text: The personal opinion of Napoleon of the British is very curious and demands a good deal of research and thought to understand. Such is my interpretation of this. I feel that Napoleon had a very strong dislike of the British, but not to the point of being completely overcome by hatred or illusions. Napoleon certainly disliked the British for being his most consistent and vehement enemy. When a British army landed in the Iberian Peninsula in 1808, Napoleon was reportedly overjoyed at the thought of finally fighting the British on terra firma. However, there were more pressing developments in Europe, and Napoleon was obliged to leave Spain in order to fight the Austrians and their new armies before fighting the British. If anything, Napoleon had many grudging admirations of British figures. He openly praised Admiral Nelson, even after the disaster at Trafalgar. Napoleon had a deep respect and appreciation for the Duke of Marlborough’s campaigns during the War of Spanish Succession (1701–1715), naming him as one of seven most important figures to study in military history. The Duke of Wellington is an interesting case. Over of the course of the Peninsular War, Napoleon expressed some admiration for the way Wellington conducted himself, and his efficiency in war, saying that Wellington did many of the things that he would do himself. Other times, Napoleon named Wellington nothing but a ‘sepoy general’. Before Waterloo, many French generals who had fought Wellington before tried to explain to Napoleon his skill at war, and Napoleon snapped at them, saying that just because he beat you doesn’t mean he is an actually good general (I do not have the exact quote). Napoleon had a deep hatred for Admiral Sydney Smith, and the feeling was well reciprocated. During the Egyptian campaign, Smith delivered to Napoleon newspapers of France’s recent defeats in Europe. Smith played an important role in Napoleon’s defeat at the Siege of Acre in 1799. I would like to end with a certain quote, taken from Gaspard Gourgaud’s Mémorial de Sainte-Hélène, “I place great value on habits of order and subordination. Look at the English! They conquered us, and yet they are very far from being our equals”.
